Whether you like tulips or sheep, there's a fair today as Hofstra University stages its 17th annual Dutch Festival from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. with 100,000 bulbs decorating the Hempstead campus, authentic ethnic food, entertainment, children's activities and a crafts sale (516) 463-6582, and the Huntington Historical Society holds its 16th annual Sheep to Shawl Festival, complete with sheep and shearings, crafts demonstrations, art projects and music and games from noon to 4 p.m. at Kissam House Museum on Park Avenue in Huntington (631) 427-7045.

Opera, Operas

The rejuvenated Long Island Opera takes a step today that few opera companies -- let alone small regional troupes -- attempt. The company will present the world premiere of a new work, ''The Sun Also Rises,'' a one-act opera by W. A. Young, the company's director. Based on the novel by Hemingway, whose estate gave Mr. Young permission to adapt it, the piece, conducted by Richard Aulden Clark, features Lawrence Harris, tenor, as Jake, the American reporter in Paris, and Luciana LaMonico, soprano, as Lady Brett Ashley. The second half of the program, at 3 p.m. at the Hays Theater on the Rockville Centre campus of Molloy College, will feature music from Mascagni's rarely performed ''Zanetto'' (516) 616-3556.

Those who prefer their opera tried and true need not fret. Today, at 2:30 p.m., Opera Pro Voce offers ''Rigoletto'' at the Baldwin Library on Grand Avenue (516) 223-6228, while on Saturday Ridotto, ''Concerts With a Touch of Theater,'' offers ''Rossini Rendezvous,'' a program of arias performed by the Ridotto Chamber Orchestra; Ron Meixsell, bass-baritone; Kim Graham, soprano; and Sahoko Sato, mezzo-soprano. It will be presented at 8 p.m. and then repeated at 4 p.m. next Sunday at the Old First Church on Route 25A in Huntington (631) 385-0373.
Those Three B's

Who could resist a concert simply called ''Billy, Bach and Beethoven?'' So get over to Hofstra University in Hempstead on Tuesday when the International Series ends its season with those three B's in a program subtitled, ''A Billy Joel Birthday Concert.'' That is, Derek Wieland, the pianist, will play works by Mr. Joel, Bach and Beethoven at 8 p.m. at the Monroe Lecture Center Theater (516) 463-6644.
Orchestral Music

With three ensembles on the boards, this is a good week for devotees of orchestral music. The West Islip Symphony Orchestra starts things off today at 3 p.m. at St. John the Baptist Auditorium on Montauk Highway in West Islip, with Warren Deck, the principal tubist for the New York Philharmonic, appearing in a program featuring music by Gregson, Khachaturian and Strauss (516) 661-8348. On Saturday, another community orchestra, the Rockaway-Five Towns Symphony Orchestra, competes with a leading professional group, the Met Orchestra, for attention. The avocational players perform music by Dvorak, Gliere and Haydn at 8 p.m. at the Lawrence Woodmere Academy on Woodmere Boulevard in Woodmere (516) 365-6857. Under James Levine's baton and with Sylvia McNair, soprano, as soloist, the Met Orchestra plays music by Bartok, Mozart, Stravinsky, Verdi and Weill at 8 p.m. at Tilles Center on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville (516) 299-3100.
Senior Games

Whether they compete in golf, bridge or racquetball, enjoy the challenge of an obstacle course or table tennis or just want to learn the newest dance steps, people over the age of 50 from the metropolitan area will join in the ''Long Island Senior Games 2000'' Thursday though next Sunday. This year, with such events as a 5K road race, cycling, lawn bowling, shuffleboard, horseshoes and duplicate bridge added, the games, for beginners as well as accomplished practitioners, will take place at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, Bethpage State Park in Farmingdale, Nassau Community College and the Garden City Bowl in Garden City and Mitchel Field in Uniondale. For a complete schedule: (631) 265-2966.
Baroque to Jazz

Concerts on both ends of the Island today run the gamut of musical styles. In Kings Point, at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Daniel Schnyder on saxophone and flute; Jonas Tauber, cellist; and David Taylor, bass trombonist, close out this year's Great Neck Arts Center's ''Salon Series'' with a tribute to Al Grey, the jazz veteran who died recently. Mr. Grey was originally booked for today's concert and the 2 p.m. performance includes Bach's ''St. Matthew Suite'' in memorium, along with works by Ellington and the performing musicians (516) 829-2570. In Southold, the Arts in Southold opens its season with the Recorder Orchestra of New York in a program of Baroque, Renaissance, Romantic and contemporary music at 3 p.m. at the High School on Oaklawn Avenue (631) 734-7696.

The Chamber Players International devotes its latest ''Musical Cuisine'' champagne brunch-concert to ''Mozart in May'' at noon at the Brookville Country Club on Chicken Valley Road in Glen Head. (877) 444-4488.
More Choral Music

Choral music's spring season continues this week with eight more entries. Today, the Silver Chords sing Broadway and Hollywood tunes at 2 p.m. at the Sayville Middle School on Johnson Avenue (631) 423-7807, while the North Fork Chorale reprises its ''2000 Spring Concert'' at 3 p.m. at the Orient Congregational Church on Main Road and then repeats it once more with feeling at 8 p.m. Saturday at the Northville First Parish Church on Sound Avenue (631) 734-4174. Also today, the Five Towns College Vocal Jazz Ensemble performs jazz and blues standards at 2:30 p.m. at the South Huntington Library on Melville Road in Huntington Station (631) 549-4411.

Tuesday brings two concerts: the Hofstra University Chorus and Hofstra Chorale offer ''Great Choral Works of the 20th Century'' featuring pieces by Barber and Stravinsky, at 8 p.m. at the Adams Playhouse (516) 463-6644, and the United Choral Society, with string ensemble, contributes Pergolesi's ''Magnificat'' at 8 p.m. at Public School 6 on Church Avenue in Woodmere (516) 781-3552. On Friday, the Northport Chorale and its Main Street Singers, perform Broadway medleys and Ellington tunes at 8:30 p.m. at Northport High School on Elwood Road (631) 368-4168. The Bel Canto Chorale sings works by Berlin, Faure and Luboff at 8 p.m. at the Cathedral of the Incarnation on Cathedral Avenue in Garden City (516) 826-6344.
Folk Music Lives

In the 1960's Club 47, the coffeehouse in Cambridge, Mass., was well-known in the world of folk music, welcoming established acts and up-and-coming artists. Tom Rush, a folk music icon, continues the tradition of that fabled venue with ''Tom Rush's Club 47,'' a touring show featuring Janis Ian and Livingston Taylor, and Vance Gilbert, a newcomer. The reincarnation comes to the Patchogue Theater on Main Street at 8 p.m. Friday (631) 286-1133.
Free Choices

TODAY -- The Greg Bravo Band, the Chiffons, Freddie Scott, Randy Jackson and Vince Martell perform an ''Oldies'' concert at 1 p.m. at Belmont Lake State Park in North Babylon. The music is free, but park admission is $5 a car and audience members are asked to bring along non-perishable food for the needy (631) 669-1000, extension 247.

The Polezhayev Family -- Vladimir, Yelena and Simon, pianists, and Anton, violinist -- play music by Handel, Mozart and Saint-Saens at 3 p.m. at Salten Hall on the Old Westbury campus of New York Institute of Technology (516) 686-7640.

Want to have your say on the best water on Long Island? The place to be is the Broadway Mall in Hicksville where the 12th Annual Best Tasting Tap Water Contest takes place from 11:30 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. and runs through Thursday. The contest, complete with educational booths, is also at the Walt Whitman Mall in Huntington Station tomorrow and Tuesday (516) 293-5700.

TUESDAY -- Giving the local library's ''2000 Memorial Fun Lecture,'' Jeffrey Toobin, author and television legal analyst, discusses ''Trials of Our Times: From Ollie to O. J. to Monica -- The Link Bewteen Politics and Law'' at 7:30 p.m. at South Side High School on Shepherd Street in Rockville Centre (516) 766-6257.

THURSDAY -- A three-woman troupe offers ''An Evening in the Drawing Room of Isabella of York,'' recreating Renaissance culture from 6 to 7:30 p.m. in Room 119 of the Islip Arts Building on the Selden campus of Suffolk Community College. Spectators are invited to come in Renaissance costume (631) 451-4336.
